summary: This is a protective order issued by Judge Alison J. Nathan in the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell. The order establishes strict rules governing the handling, use, and disclosure of discovery materials produced by the government, which are described as containing sensitive, confidential, and personal identifying information, including nude or sexualized images of individuals. The order aims to protect victim and witness privacy and prevent prejudicial pretrial publicity.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (20 Cr. 330) for which this protective order is issued. The order governs how she and her defense team can handle discovery materials.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case who issued this protective order.

events.title: Protective Order Issued
events.description: Judge Alison J. Nathan issues a protective order in the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell, setting strict rules for handling discovery materials.

keyFacts: The government's discovery materials contain sensitive information that could affect individual privacy, impede an ongoing investigation, and risk prejudicial pretrial publicity.
Discovery includes materials designated as 'Highly Confidential Information,' which contains nude, partially-nude, or otherwise sexualized images, videos, or depictions of individuals.
The protective order strictly limits who can access discovery, how it can be used (solely for defense of the criminal case), and prohibits public disclosure of victim and witness identities.
Ghislaine Maxwell is only allowed to review certain sensitive discovery materials in the presence of her defense counsel or through secure electronic access provided by the Bureau of Prisons.
